sections.title: Introduction to Servo Types
sections.content: Understanding the difference between continuous and non-continuous (standard) servos is crucial for choosing the right actuator for your robot mechanism. Each type has distinct characteristics and applications that make them suitable for different tasks.

sections.title: Key Differences
sections.subtitle: Fundamental differences between servo types:
items: Standard servos: Position control with limited rotation range
Continuous servos: Speed and direction control with full rotation
Standard servos: 0.0-1.0 represents absolute positions
Continuous servos: 0.0-1.0 represents speed and direction
Standard servos: Hold position without continuous power
Continuous servos: Require continuous power to maintain movement

sections.title: Standard (Non-Continuous) Servos
sections.content: Standard servos are the most common type used in FTC. They provide precise position control over a limited range, typically 180 degrees, and are ideal for mechanisms that need to move to specific positions and hold them.

sections.title: Standard Servo Characteristics
items: Position Control: Move to specific angles within a limited range
Rotation Range: Typically 180 degrees (0.0 to 1.0 position range)
Holding Torque: Maintain position without continuous power
Precision: High accuracy for position control
Applications: Arms, claws, flaps, mechanisms requiring precise positioning

sections.title: Standard Servo Implementation
Continuous Rotation Servos
sections.content: Continuous rotation servos are modified standard servos that can rotate continuously in both directions. They use position commands to control speed and direction rather than absolute position.

sections.title: Continuous Servo Characteristics
items: Speed Control: Position commands control rotation speed and direction
Rotation Range: Full 360-degree continuous rotation
Continuous Movement: Require continuous power to maintain rotation
Direction Control: Position 0.0-1.0 controls direction and speed
Applications: Conveyors, continuous mechanisms, material transport

sections.title: Continuous Servo Implementation
Comparison and Selection
sections.content: Understanding when to use each type of servo helps teams design effective robot mechanisms and choose the right components for their applications.

sections.title: When to Use Each Type
sections.subtitle: Selection guidelines:
items: Use Standard Servos for: Arms, claws, flaps, precise positioning
Use Continuous Servos for: Conveyors, continuous movement, material transport
Standard servos are better for: Holding positions, precise control
Continuous servos are better for: Continuous operation, speed control
Consider power consumption: Continuous servos use more power
Consider precision needs: Standard servos offer better position accuracy

sections.title: Servo Selection Helper
Control Differences
sections.content: The control methods for standard and continuous servos are fundamentally different, requiring different programming approaches and considerations.

sections.title: Control Method Differences
items: Standard Servos: Set absolute positions (0.0-1.0)
Continuous Servos: Set speed and direction (0.0-1.0)
Standard Servos: Position commands are immediate
Continuous Servos: Speed commands are continuous
Standard Servos: Can read current position
Continuous Servos: Position reading is not meaningful

sections.title: Application Examples
Troubleshooting and Best Practices
sections.content: Understanding common issues and best practices for each servo type helps teams maintain reliable robot operation.

sections.title: Troubleshooting Guide
sections.subtitle: Common issues and solutions:
items: Standard servo not moving: Check position values and mechanical binding
Continuous servo not stopping: Verify stop position (0.5) is correct
Standard servo jittering: Check for mechanical resistance or power issues
Continuous servo wrong direction: Adjust direction or invert speed values
Both types: Verify wiring and configuration file settings
